bibl.author: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman
bibl.title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [11–13 February 1873]
bibl.orgName: The Trent Collection of Whitmaniana, Duke University Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library

revisionDesc.change: removed final page break, which was for Bucke note, not LVVW content
Proofreading Corrections: Heyde dates and Silent Proof
Review proofreading Corrections, date from Feb. 11-13, annotate echoes of TJW and WW letter; add echoes of letters from Jeff on Mattie's desire to see Walt and Louisa and approaching death
Clean encoding (editor, date, remove "_large") and add standard annotations on unannotated files (Jeff W, Martha [Mattie], George W, Lou Haslam)
Encode regularization of contractions, days of week, and frequently misspelled words

body.p:
how are you this morning i would very much like to come in and see you and get your breakfast for you but as i cant can't i must content myself with writing these few lines we have had later news from poor dear mattyMatty jeffJeffie wrote the 7th
she was more comfortable and her spells of coughfing coughing was somewhat esier easier i think we shall get a letter to day from Jeffy if i doo do i will write to you again walterWalter dear i got your letter yesterd yesterday i am glad to you are gaining some if but slowly if we had a home waltWalt you might loaf as long
you wanted to but i gess guess you will be glad to get out in the open air once more i shouldent shouldn't wonder if staying in the house so much made your head worse its bad enough to have any thing the matter with the head its bad enoughf enough to be disabled any where but we cant can't run away from sickness so we have to be thankfull thankful its no wors worse i have felt very sad walterWalter dear thinking of dear mattyMatty Jeffy writes she wants to see you and me poor poor matt good bie dear waltWalt keep up your spirits and hope for the best what a good fellow petePete is
i have had quite a lot of correspondence from new york New York concerning your condition our relations
